You can see that the populist dataframe has a column called parlgov_id and our parlgov dataframe has a column called party_id. This is how we can merge the two data frames later!
However, in this script, we are only interested in West European countries.


Transform

First, we select only West European countries.
Second, the Populist starts in 1989. Therefore, we only want to keep elections in or after 1989.
Third, we are only interested in national elections. We discard European elections.


# we create a new dataframe called parlgov_west
parlgov_west <- parlgov %>% 
  # we filter the parlgov dataframe to only keep these West European countries
  filter(country_name %in% c("Germany",
                        "Austria",
                        "Switzerland",
                        "Belgium",
                        "Netherlands",
                        "France",
                        "Spain",
                        "Portugal",
                        "United Kingdom",
                        "Ireland")) %>% 
  # we only keep observations in or after 1989
  filter(election_date >= "1989-01-01") %>% 
  # we only keep national elections
  filter(election_type == "parliament")


Now, we merge the two datasets. We use the left_join function. https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/mutate-joins.html


# we create a new data frame called parl_pop
parl_pop <- parlgov_west %>% 
  # we join with the populist dataframe:
  # we keep all observations in parlgov west, and add all rows with matching party ids from the populist dataframe!
  left_join(populist, by = c("party_id" = "parlgov_id"))

The populist provides a dynamic classification of parties. Therefore, we have to check, if a party is actually Eurosceptic at the particular election.


# we "overwrite" the parl_pop dataframe
parl_pop <- parl_pop %>% 
  # we create a variable called "Eurosceptic" that takes the value "1" if 
  # it the party was considered eurosceptic before and after the election
  mutate(Eurosceptic = case_when(election_date >= eurosceptic_start & election_date <= eurosceptic_end ~ 1,
                                 TRUE ~ 0))


Now, we can restrict the dataset to the variables we are interested in for plotting!


# we create a new dataframe
parl_pop_plot <- parl_pop %>% 
  # we select only the variables we need for our first plot
  # and rename some of them in one step!
  # dplyr:select(new_name = old_name)
  dplyr::select(country = country_name.x,
                election_date,
                vote_share,
                Eurosceptic) 


As a last step, we need to summarize the vote shares of all Eurosceptic parties for each election.


# We "overwrite" our existing data frame
parl_pop_plot <- parl_pop_plot %>% 
  # before we summarize, we need to group our variables
  group_by(country, election_date, Eurosceptic) %>% 
  # now we can summarize, na.rm = TRUE omits NAs during the calculation
  # this is important as some vote_shares are missing
  summarize(Vote_share = sum(vote_share, na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'country', 'election_date'. You can
override using the `.groups` argument.




Plot
Finally, we can plot the vote share of Eurosceptic parties in West European countries over time!

# here, we are only interested in the vote share of Eurosceptic parties
# We create a new dataframe called "Eurosceptic_vote"
Eurosceptic_vote <- parl_pop_plot %>% 
  # and filter that we keep the Eurosceptic observations
  filter(Eurosceptic == 1) %>% 
  # and change election_date to date format
  mutate(election_date = as.Date(election_date))

# Now we can plot these vote shares of Eurosceptic parties
# we need out Eurosceptic_vote dataframe
ggplot(data = Eurosceptic_vote,
       # election_date at the x axis to show the development over time
       aes(x = election_date,
           # vote share on the y axis
           y = Vote_share,
           # we color by country
           color = country,
           # and tell ggplot that we need to group the observations by country
           group = country)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal()




Is a smoothed trend better?

ggplot(data = Eurosceptic_vote,
       aes(x = election_date,
           y = Vote_share,
           color = country,
           group = country)) +
  # we set se=F to avoid confidence intervals as they would overlap too much
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal()

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'





Small multiples?

# how would you produce this plot?
ggplot(data = Eurosceptic_vote,
       aes(x = election_date,
           y = Vote_share)) +
  geom_line() +
  # we can just use the facet_wrap function to produce these small multiples!
  facet_wrap(vars(country)) +
  theme_minimal()




How could we make small multiples with sparklines?

# how would you produce this plot?
ggplot(data = Eurosceptic_vote,
       aes(x = election_date,
           y = Vote_share)) +
  geom_line() +
  # again, we use facet_wrap, scales allows us that the y-axis can vary, ncol=3 just defines that we want to facet in 3 columns
  facet_wrap(vars(country), scales = "free_y", ncol= 3) +
  # theme_void gives us this "sparkline" look. We now can only concentrate on the trend. No labels etc.
  theme_void() +
  # this makes the header for each facet in bold text
  theme(strip.text = element_text(face = "bold"))






Your turn: Add manifesto data

First, you have to load the manifesto data. You can get the .csv file from ILIAS. Alternatively, you can create a free account here:https://manifesto-project.wzb.eu/datasets/MPDS2023a
In addition, you need to load the party information from the ParlGov database. This is the right file: https://www.parlgov.org/data/parlgov-development_csv-utf-8/view_party.csv


# load the parlgov party and the manifesto data here
parlgov_parties <- read.csv("https://www.parlgov.org/data/parlgov-development_csv-utf-8/view_party.csv")
CMP <- read.csv("MPDataset_MPDS2023a.csv") 


Next, you have to get the identifier from the Parlgov party data (cmp), then merge it to the the existing parlgov election data. This allows you to merge the new dataframe with the Manifesto data!

Think first about what identifiers you need to merge theses different dataframes!



# first, we need the identifier in the parlgov data to merge our exisiting dataframe with the manifesto data! This column is called "cmp". You can only know this by inspecting the codebook!

# we create a new dataframe called parlgov_parties
parlgov_parties <- parlgov_parties %>% 
  # here, we are only interested in "party_id" to merge with our existing dataframe, and in "cmp" which allows us to link the existing dataframe including the parlgov election data and the populist data with the data from the Manifesto project.
  select(party_id, cmp)

# now we create the new dataframe called "parl_pop_manifesto": 
# we start with the existing dataframe parl_pop (this includes the parlgov election data and the populist data)
parl_pop_parties <- parl_pop %>% 
  # we then join the parlgov_parties dataframe which includes only the parlgov party identifier and the identifier for the Manifesto data (cmp)
  # we can left_join by only party_id because it is both in the parl_pop and the parlgov parties dataframe
  left_join(parlgov_parties, by = c("party_id"))  %>%
  # now, we could theoretically join the Manifesto data. However, we need another identifier! 
  # in both dataframes, the party identifier appears multiple times. Therefore, it is not clear how to match!
  # we need a second identifier: the election date - we observe at each election the party once. 
  # this way, we have a unique identification. However, we need to make sure, that the election data has the same format in both dataframes.
  # it is easiest, to transform both election date variables to the date format:
  mutate(election_date = as.Date(election_date))

# here, we transform the election date (edate) in the Manifesto Project data
CMP <- CMP %>% 
  # Note, that the date is provided in a different format here!
  # We have to tell the as.Date() function the structure: "%d/%m/%Y" -> this means for example: dd.mm.YYYY 
  mutate(edate = as.Date(edate,  format = "%d/%m/%Y"))

# finally we can join the data frames
parl_pop_CMP <- parl_pop_parties %>% 
  # the party identifier in the CMP dataframe is called "party"
  left_join(CMP, by = c("cmp" = "party", "election_date" = "edate"))


Now, you can proceed as before. Select the relevant variables and plot the salience and positions regarding European integration for the Eurosceptic parties. Here, you can see how these variables are defined by the Manifesto project: https://manifesto-project.wzb.eu/information/documents/visualizations

We can add up the variables per108 and per110 to get a salience measure of European Integration (Salience): per108 + per110
We can substract per110 from per108 to get a positional measure of European Integration (Position): per108 - per110



# select and transform relevant data
# we "overwrite" the parl_pop_CMP dataframe
parl_pop_CMP <- parl_pop_CMP %>% 
  # and only selet the following variables
  select(country = country_name.x, election_date, Eurosceptic, vote_share, per108, per110) %>% 
  # then, we create the positional and salience measure of European integration:
  # we get the positional measure by substracting: per108 - per110
  mutate(position_EU = per108 - per110,
          # we get the salience measure by adding: per108 + per110
         salience_EU = per108 + per110) %>% 
  # now, we summarize the measures for the Eurosceptic parites, this is the same procedure as for the vote share before!
    # before we summarize, we need to group our variables
  group_by(country, election_date, Eurosceptic) %>% 
  # now we can summarize, na.rm = TRUE omits NAs during the calculation
  # this is important as some positions might be missing
  summarize(position_EU = sum(position_EU, na.rm = TRUE),
            salience_EU = sum(salience_EU, na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'country', 'election_date'. You can
override using the `.groups` argument.

As you can see, the aggregated position for France are always zero. The same is true for Germany and Belgium after some time. What went wrong?

Unfortunately, the party identifiers in the parlgov data set seem not to be updated regularly to match the Manifesto party identifiers. You can read more up on this here: https://manifesto-project.wzb.eu/tutorials/parlgov_merge
This means that we would have to adapt the party identifiers of Eurosceptic parties in our parl_pop_parties dataframe before we merge it with the CMP dataframe.
For France, we have a different problem. There are two rounds of elections. Unfortunately, the parlgov and Manifesto project use different rounds as election dates. One easy solution might be to transform our data variable to just the year format (e.g., YYYY). This way, we can avoid the problem that the exact dates do not match.

This is a great example that it is essential that we always check our data!

We see that the identifiers for the Left and its predecessor are 41222 and 41223. In parlgov it is 41221!
The identifier for the Alternative for Germany is 41953.
One approach to fix our problem with the German data can be to change the party identifier for the AfD in our ‚Äúparl_pop_parties‚Äù dataframe accordingly. And the party identifier in the Manifesto dataframe for the variations of the Left. We can do this easily with the case_when() function:


# we "overwrite" our parl_pop_parties dataframe
parl_pop_parties <- parl_pop_parties %>% 
  # and update the cmp column:
  # when party_name.x equals "Alternative f√ºr Deutschland" we replace the value with 41953
  # otherwise (TRUE) we keep the original cmp value.
  mutate(cmp = case_when(party_name.x == "Alternative f√ºr Deutschland" ~ 41953,
                         TRUE ~ cmp))

# now we change the identifiers for the Left party variations in the Manifesto dataframe:
CMP <- CMP %>% 
  # when party is either "The Left " or "The Left. Party of Democratic Socialism" then replace with 41221
  # Otherwise: keep the original party identifier!
  mutate(party = case_when(partyname == "The Left" | partyname == "The Left. Party of Democratic Socialism" ~ 41221,
                           TRUE ~ party))

  left_join(CMP, by = c("cmp" = "party", "election_date" = "edate"))

  filter(Eurosceptic == 1)

ggplot(data = parl_pop_CMP_Eurosceptic,
       aes(x = election_date,
           y = position_EU)) +
  geom_line() +
  # we can just use the facet_wrap function to produce these small multiples!
  facet_wrap(vars(country)) +
  theme_minimal()





Nice! We managed to plot the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù data for Germany. However, we already know one limitation. The Republicans are not included in the Manifesto Project. Though, one has to note, that the party is not significant in recent years from an electoral perspective.



Add on

You can try to correct the data for France and Belgium if you want to.



What about the salience and positions regarding European integration from non-Eurosceptic parties?
Is there a correlation between vote shares and salience/positions regarding European integration?

plot +

  annotate(geom = "label",
           x = 11250,

  labs(title = "GDP & Life Expectancy",

title: Annotations
text:
Where to place the information?

Title above + captionCaption onlyAnd now what?
















Our choice depends on the area of application:

Usually, in book or article layouts, plots do not have an integrated title and/or subtitle. We want to give the reader the information in a caption block below our plots.
If our plot is supposed to be published as a stand-alone infographic or online without surrounding text, then, we want to display titles above the plot but still use captions to provide more detailed information.

text:
Exkurs: Seeds

Computers use algorithms to generate random numbers
These algorithms start at a specific number called seed

In R: Current time + internal program process ID
Use of the same seed in random functions leads to consistent results

This is crucial for reproducible results! Also true for jittering or geom_text_repel() .

title: Session 11
text:
You can find a cheatsheet for gganimate here: https://rstudio.github.io/cheatsheets/gganimate.pdf
And the package‚Äôs vignette here: https://gganimate.com/




In order to animate the gapminder dataset, we rely on the gganimate package. It allows us to easily create GIFs.

# As usual we use our ggplot function and provide the data "gapminder"
gapminder_animated <- ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdpPercap, # GDP per capita on the x axis
                      y = lifeExp, # Life expectancy on the y-axis
                      colour = continent, # we color by continent
                      size = pop)) + # and adjust the size according to the population size
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) + # make the points transparent
  scale_size(range = c(2, 12)) + # adjust the maximum size of the points
  scale_x_log10() + # transform the x-axis to a logarithmic one
  # rename axes, and create a caption
  labs(x = "GDP per capita", 
       y = "Life expectancy", 
       caption = "Source: Gapminder. Animation created using the gganimate package") +
  # using the minimal theme
  theme_minimal() +
  # ! here the magic comes into play: transition_time defines how our data is animted.
  # frame by frame per year
  transition_time(year) +
  # now we also give the plot a title: {frame_time} adapts to the frame's respective year
  labs(title = "Year: {frame_time}") +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

# here, we safe the animated object as a GIF
anim_save("animation_gapminder.gif", gapminder_animated)

# The expression "![](animation_gapminder.gif)" outside the code chunk (below) inlcudes the GIF in the R Markdown document. We can do the same for .png or .jpeg files.

title: Session 11
text:
In order to animate the gapminder dataset, we rely on the gganimate package. It allows us to easily create GIFs.

# As usual we use our ggplot function and provide the data "gapminder"
gapminder_animated <- ggplot(gapminder, aes(x = gdpPercap, # GDP per capita on the x axis
                      y = lifeExp, # Life expectancy on the y-axis
                      colour = continent, # we color by continent
                      size = pop)) + # and adjust the size according to the population size
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) + # make the points transparent
  scale_size(range = c(2, 12)) + # adjust the maximum size of the points
  scale_x_log10() + # transform the x-axis to a logarithmic one
  # rename axes, and create a caption
  labs(x = "GDP per capita", 
       y = "Life expectancy", 
       caption = "Source: Gapminder. Animation created using the gganimate package") +
  # using the minimal theme
  theme_minimal() +
  # ! here the magic comes into play: transition_time defines how our data is animted.
  # frame by frame per year
  transition_time(year) +
  # now we also give the plot a title: {frame_time} adapts to the frame's respective year
  labs(title = "Year: {frame_time}") +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

# here, we safe the animated object as a GIF
anim_save("animation_gapminder.gif", gapminder_animated)

# The expression "![](animation_gapminder.gif)" outside the code chunk (below) inlcudes the GIF in the R Markdown document. We can do the same for .png or .jpeg files.

            selectInput(inputId = "parties", 
                        label = "Choose a party", 
                        choices = c("AfD", "CDU", "CSU",

server <- function(input, output) {
  
    output$histogram <- renderPlot({
        data %>% 
          filter(party == input$parties) %>%
          ggplot() +
            geom_histogram(aes(x = vote_share),
                           binwidth = 2.5,
                           boundary = 0) +
            scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1), 
                               limits = c(0, 80)) +
            theme_minimal() +
            labs(y = "Count",
                 x = "Vote share")
    })
}




shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

ContentQuantityQuality




Your final project should relate to a research question broadly related to political science and comparative politics.
First, you should describe the motivation for your visualization project.
Second, make a theoretical argument for the relationships you are investigating.
Third, describe the data source.
Fourth, annotate your coding (import, transformation, ‚Ä¶) extensively.






It is difficult to determine a exact ‚Äúnumber of plots‚Äù needed. Of course, you can display much more information in an interactive Shiny app than in a static dashboard.
You should produce enough plots (visualizations) to effectively address your research question. Description is totally fine!
Note: This is also where the individual office hour comes into play!






We have spoken a lot about how we can produce elegant graphs.

Remember? Contrast,¬†Repetition,¬†Alignment, and¬†Proximity

title: Tidyverse I: Import, tidy, and transform
text:
Pipes
Usually, in R we apply functions as follows:

f(x)

In the logic of pipes this function is written as:

x %>% f(.)

Here, object x is piped into function f, becoming (by default) its first argument. We can use pipes with more than one function, too:

title: Tidyverse I: Import, tidy, and transform
text:
Selecting

Generalbase Rdplyr


Usually, we do not want to work with the full data set. For example, we do not need all of the 201 variables of the GLES wave 25. Therefore, we subset our data.
This also requires that we have engaged with the data set and the codebook (if available).


In base R, there are multiple ways to subset the data.

gles_new <- gles_25[,1:10]




# we can subset the data using the select() verb

# Only the variable "study"
gles_select <- gles_25 %>% 
  select(study)

# Only the variables "study" and "kp25_011a"
gles_select <- gles_25 %>% 
  select(study, kp25_011a)

# All variables from "study" until "kp25_011a"
gles_select <- gles_25 %>% 
  select(study:kp25_011a)

Filtering

Generalbase Rdplyr


Filtering refers to rows instead of columns. We want to only include (or exclude) a specific set of observations.
Therefore, we need to use comparison or logical operators (e.g, ==, &, ‚Ä¶).



gles_filter <- gles[gles$pol_interest_state == 5,]

title: Tidyverse I: Import, tidy, and transform
text:
Recoding

GeneralGet labelsdplyr


Sometimes, we might want to recode specific values. For example, we do not want to display numeric values but their labels. We can solve this using the case_match() verb. But as always, we have multiple possibilities to do so. I prefer case_when() or if_else().



# get value labels
table(gles_25$kp25_050k, useNA = "always")


 -99  -93    1    2    3    4    5 <NA> 
  37  246  329  618 3200 3778 1822    0 





table(gles_25$kp25_050k, useNA = "always")


 -99  -93    1    2    3    4    5 <NA> 
  37  246  329  618 3200 3778 1822    0 

# Now we can recode (some of) the values
gles_25_recode <- gles_25 %>% 
  # reads: when kp25_050k is equal to 99, then assign NA,
  # otherwise, assign the existing value in kp25_050k
  mutate(new = case_when(kp25_050k == -99 ~ NA,
                         TRUE ~ kp25_050k),
         new = if_else(kp25_050k == -99, NA, kp25_050k))

table(gles_25_recode$new, useNA = "always")

Next: Group & summarize
So far:

We can generate new variables using mutate() keeping the structure of the data the same

With summarize():

we change the structure of our data frame;

and removes all variables irrelevant for computing the summary statistics.

text:
Join data
In applied research, we oftentimes need to combine multiple data sets (e.g., multiple survey waves, election statistics, ‚Ä¶).

We can use bind_cols() if two (or more) data frames have different variables (columns) but same cases (rows).
We can use bind_rows() if two (or more) data frames have the same variables (columns) but different cases (rows).

We can also use join operators from the dplyr package. These allow us to combine data frames based on a (shared) key.

Graphical excellence is the well-designed presentation of interesting data‚Äîa matter of substance, of statistics, and of design ‚Ä¶ [It] consists of complex ideas communicated with clarity, precision, and efficiency. ‚Ä¶ [It] is that which gives to the viewer the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time with the least ink in the smallest space ‚Ä¶ [It] is nearly always multivariate ‚Ä¶ And graphical excellence requires telling the truth about the data.¬†

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Design prinicples
Why would we care about design principles? What is our goal?


Communicating our data in different forms to specific audiences.
Following design principles, we can fulfill the criteria of great visualizations.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Contrast


We want to contrast various elements to get a reader‚Äôs attention.

It creates a hierarchy among different elements of your graph making it more interesting.
However, contrast must be strong!

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Repetition


We want to repeat design aspects throughout the graph for consistency.

Elements might include bullet points, typefaces, lines, colors, ‚Ä¶
Repetition makes it easier for a reader to recognize patterns and capture the graph‚Äôs message.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Alignment


We want to align the elements of our graph.

To keep our graph consistent, align every object with an edge of any other object.
Strong alignments allow you to break them occasionally to make a point without making it look like a mistake.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Proximity


We want to group together related elements of our graph.

Group elements into closer proximity if they are related.
Separate elements that are not directly related.
Vary space between groups and elements.

title: ggplot: Visualize
text:
Grammar of graphics
In general:

ggplot(data = DATA) +

Design prinicples
Why would we care about design principles? What is our goal?
. . .

Communicating our data in different forms to specific audiences.
Following design principles, we can fulfill the criteria of great visualizations.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
CRAP



Contrast
Repetition
Alignment
Proximity

These design principles apply in all areas of life: Art, architecture, ‚Ä¶, and graphs.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Contrast


We want to contrast various elements to get a reader‚Äôs attention.

It creates a hierarchy among different elements of your graph making it more interesting.
However, contrast must be strong!

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Repetition


We want to repeat design aspects throughout the graph for consistency.

Elements might include bullet points, typefaces, lines, colors, ‚Ä¶
Repetition makes it easier for a reader to recognize patterns and capture the graph‚Äôs message.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Alignment


We want to align the elements of our graph.

To keep our graph consistent, align every object with an edge of any other object.
Strong alignments allow you to break them occasionally to make a point without making it look like a mistake.

title: Designing a Graph
text:
Proximity


We want to group together related elements of our graph.

Group elements into closer proximity if they are related.
Separate elements that are not directly related.
Vary space between groups and elements.

title: Version control (Github)
section: Why should we use version control?
text:
Why should we use version control?

Good academic work entails organisation, and the recording and disseminating of it
Collaboration is much more structured and transparent with version control in place
Git and GitHub can be used for many things:

project management, saving code and outputs
hosting a personal or professional website

Rewarding: You can trace your work and accomplishments

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Git

Git is a version control system. Original purpose: help groups of developers work collaboratively on big software projects
Git manages the evolution of a set of files (called a repository or repo) in a highly structured way
Think of it as the ‚ÄúTrack Changes‚Äù feature from Microsoft Word, but more rigorous, powerful, and scaled up to multiple files
Resources: Overview of basic Git commands & Book on Git: Chacon and Straub (2014)

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Github

GitHub complements Git by providing a polished user interface and distribution mechanism for Git repositories

Git: software you will use locally to record changes to a set of files
GitHub: a hosting service for such projects.

Many operations can be done entirely in the browser
GitHub also offers granular control over who can see, edit, and administer a project
You can apply for a free GitHub Pro account for students!

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Username. Who cares?

Incorporate your actual name in your username!
Reuse your username from other contexts, e.g., Twitter (‚Äúprofessional‚Äù social media)
Pick a (short) username you will be comfortable revealing in applications.
Don‚Äôt highlight your current university, employer, or place of residence
More info & tips

Terms

Repository/Repo: directory of files that Git manages holistically



Commit: a snapshot of all the files in the repo, at a specific moment. Under the hood, that is not exactly how Git implements things
Commit message: every time you make a commit you must also write a short commit message
Pull request: submitting contributions to a project
Branch: diverge from the main line of development and continue to do work without messing with that main line
For more information see: https://git-scm.com/doc

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Setup: How to get started

Register for a free account with GitHub
Install Git. Depending on your OS, Git might already be installed. Usually, you will need to install it or update it to a more recent version
Install a local Git client (e.g., SourceTree, GitKraken, GitHub Desktop). A Git client provides a graphical user interface for Git, which is otherwise command-line only. We will use GitHub Desktop.

‚Üí Once this setup is done, you are ready to start using Git and GitHub

title: Version control (Github)
text:
How to structure your project?

Have a local folder for all of your projects that you want to host on GitHub
For example:

GitHub

bachelor-thesis
seminar_x
seminar_y


You can set up new repositories at github.com or via GitHub Desktop

title: Version control (Github)
text:
What should we commit?
Source files: These files are created and edited by hand, such as R or Python scripts, R Markdown or LaTeX files. This could also include the raw data for an analysis.
Configuration files: These files modify the behavior of a tool, for example .gitignore (identify files or file formats that should not be committed)
Derived products: These files are programmatically generated from source files and have external value. By executing .R or rendering .Rmd files, you obtain artifacts such as intermediate data (e.g., .csv or .rds), figures (e.g., .png or .pdf), and reports (e.g., .md, .pdf, .docx, or .html)

title: Version control (Github)
text:
What not to commit?

Rule of thumb: a file (e.g., intermediate data) that is large and changing often can make your repository bloated and slow down pushes and pulls (speaking from experience!)
You can exclude files from commits by adding it to the .gitignore file

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Branches

So far, we only used the main branch. But you can commit, push, and pull to more than one branch
A branch is an independent line of development within a repo, where the intent is usually to merge it into the main branch when ready.
You can make edits in a separate branch and test what works. When you are happy with the changes, you can commit to this branch.
Make sure you are in the desired branch when working on your project!

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Pull requests

A pull request is a GitHub-specific way to propose changes to a repo that overlays Git‚Äôs regular branch and merge workflow with facilities for structured review.
A pull request can be made between two branches in the same repo, such as main
Especially useful/necessary in collaborative projects
Also useful if you experiment and change code in your personal project

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Conflicts

Conflicts occur when there are competing line changes in two branches
Common in collaborative projects
Requires time and effort but makes sure that everyone involved knows what has been changed
How to handle conflicts is beyond the scope of today‚Äôs session but see: resolving a merge conflict on GitHub

title: Version control (Github)
text:
Take aways

Version control is important & can be motivating and rewarding
Reproducible research is key and required for most journals
Allows you to go ‚Äúback in time‚Äù and spot changes and errors
Prepares you for collaborative projects and software development

‚Üí Knowing about version control is a very useful skill!

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Legal Issues

Web scraping could be illegal!

it depends: Who is web scraping what sites? How is the scraping conducted? Under which jurisdiction?

The following represent possible illegal web scraping activities:

web scraping results in collapse of website (too many and large inquiries)
collecting (private) copyright data and use it for own gain (e.g., selling e-mail adresses)

title: Web scraping basics
text:
Ethical Issues

Web scraping could also be unethical!

again, it depends: Who, what, why, and how?

The following represent possible unethical web scraping activities:

not respecting restrictions set by the website administrator (e.g., robots.txt files)
collecting data in short time-intervals without need which is available to download via an API

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Files

Most websites provide a so-called robots exclusion protocol

it includes information on what is allowed to scrape and at what speed
the information is stored within robots.txt files

the can be found via the websites URL: e.g., www.EXAMPLE.com/robots.txt


These rules are not binding, so you could scrape the website however you want.

BUT: legal and ethical issues!

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Syntax

GeneralSyntaxExample



robots.txt files are easy to read and understand

we can make use of the robotstxt package





User-agent: Who is the protocol intended for?
Allow: What part of the website can be scraped?
Disallow: What part of the website is not allowed to be scraped?
Crawl-delay: How fast should we scrape the website?







The key always starts with capital letters and is followed by a colon.






User-agent:
Allow:
Disallow:
Crawl-delay:

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Syntax

ExampleCode


Websites define the keys themselves:

*: protocol is targeted at everyone
/: full website can be scraped
/about/: this specific path is not allowed to be scraped
numeric values for Crawl-delay: are given in seconds




User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /about/
Crawl-delay: 10

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Example

User-agent: googlebot
Allow: /

This websites‚Äô protocol is only for Google:

Google is allowed to scrape everything without any restrictions
No defined rule for anyone else

text:
robots.txt Example

ExampleMeaning



User-agent: googlebot
Disallow: /about/
Disallow: /history/
Crawl-delay: 60



This websites‚Äô protocol is only for Google:

Google is disallowed to scrape two specific paths
Only allowed to access at 60-seconds intervals
No defined rule for anyone else

title: Web scraping basics
text:
robots.txt Example

ExampleMeaning



User-agent: googlebot
Allow: /
Crawl-delay: 5

User-agent: bing
Disallow: /
  
User-agent: *
Allow: /companyinfo/



This websites‚Äô protocol is for different user agents:

Google is allowed to scrape everything in 60-second intervals
Bing is not allowed to scrape anything
Everyone else can scrape the section or page located at www.EXAMPLE.com/companyinfo/

robots.txt Additional Information
The key Visit-time is less often used:

User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /impressum/

robots.txt files can also include comments (preceded by #)

# This is a robots.txt file

User-agent: *
Allow: /
Disallow: /impressum/
Visit-time: 00:00-06:00 # visit website during night time in Germany

title: Web scraping basics
section: Ethical Issues: Speed, Purpose, and Storage
text:
Ethical Issues: Speed, Purpose, and Storage

Speed: repeated, automatic web scraping in very short-time intervals can lead to overloading a website‚Äôs server

waiting time might be defined in protocol (Crawl-delay key)

Purpose: in the best case scenario, we have already a research question of hypothesis in mind before collecting (web scraping) data
Storage: often, we will need lots of storage place (big data)

data should be stored privately and safely

HTML - Syntax / Tags
Most elements have opening and closing tags:
<p> This is a paragraph. </p>

The tag name, here p, defines structure of the element; the closing tag has a forward slash / before element name

HTML - Syntax / Attributes
Elements might have attributes
<p>This is <strong id="count-sentence">one</strong> sentence.</p> 
This is one sentence.






Attributes are added to the opening tags (separated with a white space) - the id attribute has no visible effects - other attributes (e.g., style can have visible effects!)

There can be more than one attribute in a single element:
<p>This is <strong class="count" id="count-sentence">one</strong> sentence.</p> 

<p>This is <strong class="count" id="count-paragraph">one</strong> paragraph.</p> 
This is one sentence.
This is one paragraph.






The same class attribute can apply to multiple elements (here: count)

HTML - Links
Links are provided with the a (anchor) element
<p>Click <a href="https://www.uni-mannheim.de/">here</a> for the university's website.</p>
Click here for the university‚Äôs website.






href (hypertext reference) is a required attribute for this element - most attributes are optional, but some are required

<p>Click <a title="This text appears when visitors hover over the link"
href="https://www.uni-mannheim.de/">here</a> to get to the university's website.</p>
Click here to get to the university‚Äôs website.






Note


The title attribute is one of the optional attributes - becomes visible when hovered over.

<p>This is an <`span` style="text-decoration: underline;">important paragraph<`/span`>, which

Containers are useful in applying styles to sections

text
images

SelectorsDeclarationExamples


CSS syntax consists of one or more selectors, matching one or more HTML elements or attributes







syntax changes with selector type

elements and attributes are written as they are
classes are prefixed with a full stop
ids with a hashtag

the same rule can be defined for more than one element or attribute






CSS syntax consists of a declaration, with one or more properties and values







values are followed by a semicolon
property:value; pairs are separated by a white space

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Overview
Dynamic pages display custom content.
Different visitors see different content on the same page - e.g., depending on their input (clicking, scrolling) - URL stays the same
For example, the Bundeswahlleiter (Federal Returining Officer) has dynamic elements on its website (e.g., selecting election year or voting results on subnational levels).
It is more difficult to scrape dynamic than static pages - we need one extra step - for this extra step, we are using the package RSelenium

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: Steps
Three main steps:

Use RSelenium to identify and select the desired elements of the page by clicking, searching, selecting from within RStudio
Get the source code

RSelenium downloads in XML format
we can use rvest to transform this into HTML

Extract the relevant information from the source code using the rvest package

this is the same process as for static pages

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Dynamic Pages: RSelenium
The RSelenium package integrates the Selenium 2.0 WebDriver into R. The package allows us to interact with

browsers on our device (e.g., open a browser and navigating to a page)
elements on a page (e.g., opening or clicking on a drop-down menu)

In case you are stuck on a particular problem, you can easily find help for only (e.g., stackoverflow, google, etc.) or more information in the vignette.

title: Web scraping dynamic
text:
Starting a Server With Firefox
We use the rsDriver function to start a server. This way we can control a browser of our choice from within R.

The function rsDriver creates the object driver and the web browser opens
You should avoid controlling this browser manually
You should avoid creating multiple servers
Note: We can start only one server per port


driver <- RSelenium::rsDriver(port = 0001L, 
                              browser = "firefox",
                              ...
                              )

library(shiny)
library(bslib)
library(tidyverse)

data <- readRDS("data/constituency_shapes_vote.RDS")




ui <- page_sidebar(
      title = "2017 German election data",
      sidebar = sidebar(
        selectInput(
          inputId = "parties", 
          label = "Choose a party", 
          choices = c("AfD", "CDU", "CSU", 
                      "Left" = "DIE LINKE", 
                      "FDP", 
                      "Greens" = "GR√úNE", 
                      "SPD"), 
          selected = "AfD"
        )
      ),
    
    plotOutput("histogram")
)




server <- function(input, output) {
  
  output$histogram <- renderPlot({
    
    data %>% 
      filter(party == input$parties) %>%
      ggplot() +
      geom_histogram(aes(x = vote_share),
                     binwidth = 2.5,
                     boundary = 0) +
      scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1), 
                         limits = c(0, 80)) +
      theme_minimal() +
      labs(y = "Count",
           x = "Vote share")
  })
}




shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

title: Intro to R
text:
Using R as a calculator
The simplest application is to use R as a calculator:

1 + 1

[1] 2





1 / 10

[1] 0.1





2 * 2

[1] 4

title: Intro to R
text:
Commenting code
We can comment our code using the #. Input thereafter will not be executed as code.

# Addition
1 + 1

[1] 2





2 * 2 # 2 times 2 should equal four

[1] 4


Typically, we want to comment our code extensively for replicability and reusability.

title: Intro to R
text:
Functions
Functions are essential for our workflow in R. They take input(s) as argument, and produce output(s) depending on the input.

sqrt(100)

[1] 10

title: Intro to R
text:
Objects I
R is an object-oriented programming language.

Therefore, we can store single values, multiple values, character strings, etc. in an object.
We can assign a single value to an object using the assignment operator <-


# here we assign the numeric value 10 to the object x:
x <- 10

# we can do the same for a character string:
y <- "This is a character string"

title: Intro to R
text:
Objects II
We can also store the output of functions in objects:

# here, we calculate the square root of 100 
# and store it in a object called "result"
result <- sqrt(100)

Further, we can also do calculations with objects:

# here we add our two objects and store the result in z
z <- x + result

Finally, we can print the object to the console by typing its name:

# z should print the number 20 (10 + sqrt(10))
z

[1] 20

title: Intro to R
text:
Packages

Packages allow us to go beyond base R functionalities.
They consist of various functions that simplify tasks and provide documentation.



We can install packages from within R via CRAN:


# we need to install packages only once:
install.packages("stringr")

# however, we need to load the package every time we (re-)start R
library(stringr)

title: Intro to R
text:
Example: stringr

# lets load the stringr package:
library(stringr)

# using the help() function, we can inspect the documentation
help(stringr)

title: Intro to R
text:
Example: stringr
The stringr package provides us with multiple functions to manipulate strings.

# as an example, we create a fictitious actor ID from the Twitter API
string <- "id:twitter.com:207584738373"

# to match this ID with meta data, we only want to keep the numbers
# we can make use of the function str_replace()
# It needs these arguments: str_replace(string, pattern, replacement)
clean_ID <- str_replace(string, "id:twitter.com:", "")

# let's check if it worked:
clean_ID

[1] "207584738373"

title: Intro to R
text:
Numeric values
There are two types in R: Integers (numbers without a decimal values) and doubles (numbers with decimal values)

# We place an L behind the value to be specific that it is an integer
x <- 10L

# using the typeof() function we can check the data type
typeof(x)

[1] "integer"



# create a double
z <- 10.55

# check data type
typeof(z)

[1] "double"



# is x numeric?
is.numeric(x)

[1] TRUE

title: Intro to R
text:
Character strings
A string represents a series of characters. Numbers and/or symbols can also be part of a string.

# we need to wrap the string into quotation marks

string <- "Hello"

# we can check the type using class()
class(string)

[1] "character"

# an example with numbers
ID <- "id:twitter.com:207584738373"

# check again
class(string)

[1] "character"

title: Intro to R
text:
Factors
We call data types that assume that their values are not continuous and have distinct categories factors.
Factors take numeric values or character strings as input and convert them into so-called levels:

# let's create an factor:
factor(1)

[1] 1
Levels: 1

title: Intro to R
text:
Logical values
They are either TRUE or FALSE (and also called Boolean values). We produce them by making logical requests:

1 > 2

[1] FALSE


We can also store logical values is objects:

logical <- 1 > 2

logical

[1] FALSE

title: Intro to R
text:
Logical operators

RelationalLogical



< less than
<= less than or equal to
> greater than
>= greater than or equal to
== exactly equal to
!= not equal to




& (AND)
| (OR)

title: Intro to R
text: Data formats

title: Intro to R
text:
Vector
We can create vectors by combining individual objects with the function c() (‚Äúconcatenating‚Äù):

# This works for numbers
numeric_vector <- c(1,2,3)

numeric_vector

[1] 1 2 3



# ... for characters
character_vector <- c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD")

character_vector

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"



# and for logical values
logical_vector <- c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)

logical_vector

[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE

title: Intro to R
text:
Data frames
They are comparable to data sets as in Stata or SPSS

with n rows and k columns
and allow us to store variables of different classes.


# we create a data frame called df 
# using the function "data.frame()
df <- data.frame(
  party = c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD"),
  vote_share = c("27", "5", "13")
)

. .

df

  party vote_share
1   CDU         27
2   CSU          5
3   SPD         13

title: Intro to R
text:
Data frames
We can also check the dimensions, number of observations, and number of variables:

# dimensions
dim(df)

[1] 3 2

# number of observations
nrow(df)

[1] 3

# number of variables
ncol(df)

[1] 2

title: Intro to R
text:
Lists
We can combine any number of objects to a list:

# using the list() function
test_list <- list(numeric_vector,
                  character_vector)

test_list

[[1]]
[1] 1 2 3

[[2]]
[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting objects

Typically, we are not interested in all of the data
We want to access specific information
This works similar across different object types (vectors, data frames, lists, ‚Ä¶)


# Let's go back to our party vector:
party_vector <- c("CDU", "CSU", "SPD")

# we only want to access the first element
party_vector[1]

[1] "CDU"



# we can store this in a new object:
CDU <- party_vector[1]

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting data frames
We can select rows, columns, and specific elements. This follows the general logic:

data_frame[specify_row, specify_column]

Let‚Äôs try this:

# This is our data frame
df

  party vote_share
1   CDU         27
2   CSU          5
3   SPD         13

# Let's select only the first column
df[,1]

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"

title: Intro to R
text:
Accessing and subsetting data frames
We can also access individual variables using the $ sign:

df$party

[1] "CDU" "CSU" "SPD"


Alternatively, we can index by variable name:

df["party"]

  party
1   CDU
2   CSU
3   SPD


Or variable order:

df[1]

  party
1   CDU
2   CSU
3   SPD
